description: This course presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.
name: INTRO TO LAW & LEG PROC

values.comments: This course presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.   Students agreed that this is both “a fantastic class” and “a MUST TAKE if you can get in!” Each lecture proved “interesting and engaging.” One student commented that this course was a “Riveting class that made me genuinely interested to learn the material.” Students strongly recommend this course for both majors and non-majors alike. Students further felt the material was presented clearly and thoroughly.   Students gave Professor Miller overwhelmingly positive remarks, commenting that he “is an amazing teacher”, “a great lecturer”, and “makes an otherwise dull subject engaging and entertaining.” Several students commented that he is the best professor they have had at Penn. Students further agreed that Professor Miller’s “enthusiasm is contagious” and that he was “friendly” and “hilarious”. Some students, however, felt that he could have been more available to students.   Students commented that this course required little “work required outside the two quizzes and two tests.” Students agreed the exams were “hard”, but also “straightforward” if the material was reviewed well. Others felt that “a paper analyzing a case or legal issue” might also be beneficial, rather than just exams. Some students remarked that they would have liked a “review session before the midterm or final.” Some students further commented that the assigned readings were not relevant for exams, and the material presented in lecture was much more useful.
